workflow.name: MX Firewall - Block Outbound Traffic by Tags
workflow.title: MX Firewall - Block Outbound Traffic by Tags

properties.name: Result
properties.description: LLM-generated comprehensive summary of firewall rule deployment results across all processed networks, including successful and failed operations with detailed information.

properties.name: Temp Message
properties.description: Temporary variable used to accumulate and format output messages from multiple network processing operations.

properties.name: Error Message
properties.description: Detailed error message providing specific information about workflow failures including validation errors, API failures, network discovery issues, or firewall rule deployment problems for troubleshooting and resolution.

properties.name: Block Destination IP Address
properties.description: Destination IP address or CIDR block to block outbound traffic to. Supports single IPs (e.g., 192.168.1.1) or CIDR notation (e.g., 10.0.0.0/8). This will be blocked across all matching networks.

properties.name: Status Code
properties.description: The HTTP status code of the workflow execution.

properties.name: Status Message
properties.description: Overall execution status message indicating successful completion or high-level error information for the bulk firewall rule deployment operation.

properties.name: Enable Jira Tracking
properties.description: Enable or disable Jira issue creation and tracking for this firewall deployment. When enabled, a Jira issue will be created and updated throughout the workflow execution.

properties.name: Network Tags to Search
properties.description:
Provide a list of network tags to search. Only networks in the user's organization with at least one matching tag from this list will be included. Note: The filtering is case-sensitive.
Example:
[
  "example-tag", "another-tag"
]

properties.name: Jira Issue ID
properties.description: Stores the ID of the created Jira issue for use in subsequent comment operations throughout the workflow execution.

properties.name: Jira Issue Type ID
properties.description: The Jira Issue Type ID for the tracking issue (e.g., '11018' for Bug, '10001' for Task). Check your Jira administration settings for the correct issue type ID.

properties.name: Jira Project ID
properties.description: The Jira Project ID where the tracking issue will be created. This should be the numeric project ID (e.g., '10004') that can be found in your Jira project settings.

This workflow blocks outbound traffic to a specified destination IP/CIDR across multiple Meraki MX networks based on network tags. It automatically discovers networks with matching tags and adds a deny firewall rule to block traffic to the specified destination.

The workflow creates outbound L3 firewall rules with deny policy for the provided destination across all matching networks.

Prerequisites:
- User must have network admin privileges for target organizations
- Target networks must exist, have specified tags, and support MX appliances
- Valid destination IP address or CIDR block

Features:
- Automatic network discovery by tags
- Bulk firewall rule deployment
- Comprehensive error handling and reporting
- AI-powered result summarization

Limitations:
- Maximum 500 networks per organization query
- Case-sensitive tag matching
- Requires valid IP/CIDR format for destination
properties.display_name: MX Firewall - Block Outbound Traffic by Tags

properties.description: Parse ServiceNow incident webhook payload using LLM to extract CIDR block and network region tags for automated firewall rule deployment targeting.

chat_messages.content:
Extract the CIDR block and network region from this ServiceNow incident payload:

$workflow.definition_workflow_02Q1QSQT8A6T01nq4Xm61AwFBo6TiZW2WB5.input.variable_workflow_02Q3QSTLSDE6F4BEoEtuzNrfL3fIoMMCh4b$

Focus on the 'description' field which contains the incident details. Extract the CIDR block and regional network tags from this description text.
Extract the 'number' to capture the Incident Number.

properties.description: Extract the CIDR block and network region from the ServiceNow incident text using structured LLM parsing.

system_messages.content:
You are a network security analyst expert at extracting critical information from ServiceNow incident webhook payloads. Your job is to identify CIDR blocks and network regions that require immediate firewall blocking.

Key extraction rules:
1. Parse the JSON payload and focus on the 'description' field
2. Look for CIDR notation (e.g., 203.0.113.0/24) or IP addresses in the description
3. Find regional identifiers and ALWAYS convert them to standardized network tags:
   - 'East Coast', 'east coast', 'US-East-Region', 'region:east-coast' ‚Üí 'US-East-Region'
   - 'West Coast', 'west coast', 'US-West-Region', 'region:west-coast' ‚Üí 'US-West-Region' 
   - 'North America', 'US', 'USA' ‚Üí 'US-Region'
   - 'Europe', 'EU' ‚Üí 'EU-Region'
4. If multiple CIDRs are mentioned, extract the primary threat CIDR
5. ALWAYS return standardized network tag format for network_region

Example input: {"description": "Emergency Security Block - CIDR 203.0.113.0/24 targeting East Coast retail..."}
Expected output: {"cidr_block": "203.0.113.0/24", "network_region": "US-East-Region"}

Be precise and focus on actionable network security information from the description field. Always standardize regional descriptions to proper network tags.

user_messages.content:
Extract the CIDR block and network region from this ServiceNow incident payload:

$workflow.definition_workflow_02Q1QSQT8A6T01nq4Xm61AwFBo6TiZW2WB5.input.variable_workflow_02Q3QSTLSDE6F4BEoEtuzNrfL3fIoMMCh4b$

Focus on the 'description' field which contains the incident details. Extract the CIDR block and regional network tags from this description text.

properties.systemPrompt:
You are a network security analyst expert at extracting critical information from ServiceNow incident webhook payloads. Your job is to identify CIDR blocks and network regions that require immediate firewall blocking along with Incident number for tracking.

Key extraction rules:
1. Parse the JSON payload and focus on the 'description' and 'number' fields
2. Look for CIDR notation (e.g., 203.0.113.0/24) or IP addresses in the description
3. Find regional identifiers and ALWAYS convert them to standardized network tags:
   - 'East Coast', 'east coast', 'US-East-Region', 'region:east-coast' ‚Üí 'US-East-Region'
   - 'West Coast', 'west coast', 'US-West-Region', 'region:west-coast' ‚Üí 'US-West-Region' 
   - 'North America', 'US', 'USA' ‚Üí 'US-Region'
   - 'Europe', 'EU' ‚Üí 'EU-Region'
4. If multiple CIDRs are mentioned, extract the primary threat CIDR
5. ALWAYS return standardized network tag format for network_region

Be precise and focus on actionable network security information from the description field. Always standardize regional descriptions to proper network tags.

import sys
import json

# Get the network tags input
tags_input = sys.argv[1]

# Check if array is empty

    errorMessage = "Network tags array is empty. At least one tag must be provided."
else:
    isValid = True
    errorMessage = ""

properties.workflow_name: Jira Cloud - Add Comment to Issue

properties.description: Builds a properly formatted L3 firewall rule JSON structure from the input destination IP/CIDR. Creates a deny rule for outbound traffic with automation tracking via comments.
properties.script:
import json
import sys

# Get the destination IP address from workflow input
destination = sys.argv[1] if len(sys.argv) > 1 else ""

if not destination:
    print("Error: No destination IP address provided")
    sys.exit(1)

# Build the firewall rule JSON structure using the provided format
newRule = {
    "comment": "Updated by Cisco Workflows Automation ($activity.definition_activity_02Q3RY9ULP3P120AUXnCn3t7LiHQOZ4CSCs.output.jsonpath_queries.incidentNumber$ - $workflow.definition_workflow_02Q1QSQT8A6T01nq4Xm61AwFBo6TiZW2WB5.local.variable_workflow_02Q42ODEFXUVA0rrvljIeVamnn4Ga4g1qko$)",
    "destCidr": destination,
    "destPort": "any",
    "policy": "deny",
    "protocol": "any",
    "srcCidr": "any",
    "srcPort": "any",
    "syslogEnabled": False
}

# Convert to JSON string and output
ruleJson = json.dumps(newRule, indent=2)
print(f"Built firewall rule for destination {destination}")
print(f"Rule JSON: {ruleJson}")

workflow.name: Meraki - Manage MX L3 Firewall Rules
workflow.title: Meraki - Manage MX L3 Firewall Rules

properties.name: Position
properties.description: Rule insertion position in firewall list (0-based index). 0=highest priority (first rule), 1=second rule, etc. Only used when Add or Remove Rule=true. Values beyond rule count insert at end. Negative values insert at beginning.

properties.name: Status Message
properties.description: Brief status message indicating workflow outcome. Examples: 'Success: Firewall rule operation completed', 'Validation Error: Invalid policy value', 'Error: GET operation failed'. Useful for quick status checks.

properties.name: Result
properties.description: Comprehensive summary of firewall rule operation including network ID, operation performed, rule details, and success/failure status. Useful for logging and monitoring workflow executions.

properties.name: Error Message
properties.description: Detailed error message when workflow fails. Includes specific validation errors, API failures, or processing issues to help troubleshoot problems.

properties.name: Rule
properties.description: JSON object defining the firewall rule to add. Required fields: policy (allow/deny), protocol (any/tcp/udp/icmp), destPort, destCidr, srcPort, srcCidr. Optional: comment, syslogEnabled. Example: {"policy":"deny","protocol":"tcp","destPort":"22","destCidr":"any","srcPort":"any","srcCidr":"192.168.1.0/24","comment":"Block SSH from internal"}

properties.name: Status Code
properties.description: HTTP status code returned by the Meraki API operations. Common values: 200 (success), 400 (validation error), 401 (unauthorized), 404 (network not found), 429 (rate limited).

properties.name: Network ID
properties.description: Meraki network identifier where firewall rules will be managed. Format: N_XXXXXXXXXX. Must be a valid MX network with Layer 3 firewall capabilities. Found in Meraki Dashboard under Network-wide > General.

properties.name: Add or Remove Rule
properties.description: Operation mode: true = Add new firewall rule at specified position, false = Remove all automation-created rules. When adding, uses Rule and Position inputs. When removing, ignores Rule and Position inputs.

Manages Meraki MX Layer 3 outbound firewall rules with add/remove operations and position-based insertion. Includes comprehensive validation and error handling.

Features:
- Add new firewall rules at specified position (0=first/highest priority, 1=second, etc.)
- Use comment field exactly as provided in Rule input
- Remove existing automation rules (identified by workflow comment)
- Input validation for required fields (policy, protocol, destPort, destCidr, srcPort, srcCidr)
- Error handling for GET/UPDATE operations
- Comprehensive output variables
- Position validation with automatic boundary adjustment

properties.description: API endpoint is used to retrieve the Layer 3 (L3) firewall rules configured on a network appliance. Layer 3 firewall rules control traffic based on IP addresses, protocols, and ports, allowing administrators to manage traffic flows and secure the network.

variables_to_update.variable_value_new: Failed to retrieve firewall rules for Network ID: $workflow.definition_workflow_02Q2Q77WT8QTE4UkIuKUVeySa9Viy5opNWU.input.variable_workflow_02Q2QBASBNJPU4Jb0bAtz75rsEjBfxWl1zC$. Error: $activity.definition_activity_02Q2Q78SQ9K1F74GEslWWM4grvtwqaSkPgS.output.error.message$
Failed to retrieve or modify firewall rules due to GET operation failure.

properties.description: Gracefully terminate workflow when GET firewall rules fails. Completes with success status but comprehensive error details in outputs.
Extract the 'rules' array from the GET firewall rules API response to prepare for rule modification.
Process firewall rules based on Add/Remove boolean and Position. Add: checks for duplicates and inserts rule at specified position if no duplicate found. Remove: removes matching rules by key fields.
properties.script:
import sys, json

existingRules = sys.argv[1]  # This is already the rules array, not full response
ruleInput = sys.argv[2]
addOrRemove = sys.argv[3].lower() == 'true'  # true = add, false = remove
position = int(sys.argv[4])  # position to insert rule

# Parse inputs - existingRules is already just the rules array
rulesArray = json.loads(existingRules)
newRule = json.loads(ruleInput)

# Filter out the default rule from existing rules (API update should not include it)
# Default rule format: comment="Default rule", policy="allow", protocol="Any/any", all ports/CIDRs="Any/any"
user_rules = []
for rule in rulesArray:
    is_default_rule = (
        rule.get('comment', '') == 'Default rule' and
        rule.get('policy', '').lower() == 'allow' and
        rule.get('protocol', '').lower() == 'any' and
        rule.get('destCidr', '').lower() == 'any' and
        rule.get('srcCidr', '').lower() == 'any' and
        rule.get('destPort', '').lower() == 'any' and
        rule.get('srcPort', '').lower() == 'any'
    )
    if not is_default_rule:
        user_rules.append(rule)

if addOrRemove:
    # Add rule - first check for duplicates against ALL existing rules (including default), then insert at specified position
    # Use comment as provided in input (or empty string if not provided)
    if 'comment' not in newRule:
        newRule['comment'] = ""
    
    # Define the key fields to check for duplicates (exclude comment and syslogEnabled)
    key_fields = ['policy', 'protocol', 'destPort', 'destCidr', 'srcPort', 'srcCidr']
    
    # Check if a rule with the same key fields already exists in ALL rules (including default rule)
    # Use case-insensitive comparison for field values
    duplicate_found = False
    for existing_rule in rulesArray:  # Check against ALL rules, not just user_rules
        if all(existing_rule.get(field, '').lower() == newRule.get(field, '').lower() for field in key_fields):
            duplicate_found = True
            break
    
    if duplicate_found:
        # Don't add duplicate rule
        result = f"Duplicate rule detected."
        newRules = json.dumps(user_rules)  # Return unchanged user rules (no default rule)
        skipUpdate = True
    else:
        # No duplicate found, proceed with adding the rule
        # Ensure position is within valid range for user rules
        max_position = len(user_rules)
        if position > max_position:
            position = max_position  # Insert at end if position too high
        elif position < 0:
            position = 0  # Insert at beginning if position negative
        
        user_rules.insert(position, newRule)
        result = f"Rule added successfully at position {position} (no duplicate found)"
        newRules = json.dumps(user_rules)  # Return user rules without default rule
        skipUpdate = False
else:
    # Remove rule - find and remove matching rules by comparing key fields among user rules
    original_count = len(user_rules)
    
    # Define the key fields to match for rule identification
    key_fields = ['policy', 'protocol', 'destPort', 'destCidr', 'srcPort', 'srcCidr']
    
    # Filter out rules that match ALL key fields of the input rule (case-insensitive)
    filtered_rules = [rule for rule in user_rules 
                     if not all(rule.get(field, '').lower() == newRule.get(field, '').lower() for field in key_fields)]
    
    user_rules = filtered_rules
    removed_count = original_count - len(user_rules)
    
    if removed_count == 0:
        result = f"No matching rule found to remove"
        skipUpdate = True  # No changes to make
    elif removed_count == 1:
        result = f"Successfully removed 1 matching rule"
        skipUpdate = False  # Changes made, need to update
    else:
        # This shouldn't happen in normal scenarios but handle it defensively
        result = f"Warning: Removed {removed_count} identical rules (unexpected)"
        skipUpdate = False  # Changes made, need to update
    
    # Output user rules array without default rule
    newRules = json.dumps(user_rules)

print(newRules)
